It is hard to conceive how Randazzo would be considered a “fiduciary” given her demotion by Mancinelli. In the context of all her circumstances Randazzo was the one who was “vulnerable”. There was an obvious power imbalance in favour of Mancinelli which belied any vulnerability to or dependence upon Randazzo. The categorization of Randazzo as a fiduciary would torture the concept.[99]

However, once the potential for a raid was accepted by the Carpenters and employment was offered, Randazzo was precluded from any steps such as solicitation in furtherance thereof, for the duration of her employment with LiUNA. By not providing LiUNA with any notice, the defendant employees got the jump on Local 1110 in the open period of the 4 W's. Local 1110 had to scramble to compete. The complete absence of a notice period by the defendant employees was particularly egregious in that it was accompanied by competition “during employment” with LiUNA, their employer. Randazzo's breach of her duties to exercise good faith and loyalty/fidelity to LiUNA was not of such a magnitude that it elevated her role to that of fiduciary employee, but it should be compensated for by an award of damages. Randazzo was to pay the plaintiffs Local 1110 $15,000.[100]

On appeal in Guzzo v. Randazzo,[101] the Appellants submitted that the trial judge erred in not finding that Randazzo was a fiduciary and that she breached that fiduciary duty to Local 1110. They also argued that the damages awarded to be paid by certain Respondents to the Appellants did not reflect the damages caused by their conduct.[102]

The Appellants argued that the trial judge made a palpable and overriding error in failing to find Randazzo to be a fiduciary. It is undisputed that there exists jurisprudence to support the general conclusion that officers of a union may hold a fiduciary position with respect to the union and its members. To find a fiduciary relationship, what is generally required is evidence of a mutual understanding that one party has relinquished her own self-interest and agreed to act solely on behalf of the other party. Fiduciary obligations tend to be imposed only where one party is, in reality, at the mercy of the other and places total reliance and dependent on the fiduciary. As a result, whether a fiduciary obligation exists must be decided based on the particular circumstances of each case. The trial judge considered that even the fact that an employee may be a key employee or the fact that the employer may be vulnerable are not absolutely determinative of the imposition of a fiduciary relationship and the obligations that flow from that designation. Those are simply two factors among many to be considered. The trial judge made several findings of fact, supported by the evidence, which served to characterize Randazzo's power and influence over the Appellants as being quite limited. Given the provisional nature of Local 1110's charter, it could be amended, revoked and consolidated abruptly and without notice. Although the Executive Board tended to agree with any recommendations made by Randazzo it was not obliged to do so. Randazzo had no cheque-signing authority. Although she had employees reporting to her, she could not employ or dismiss employees, set employment policies or rates of pay, or establish budgets without approval of the Executive Board. Randazzo was not directly responsible to the local union membership. In addition, although Randazzo could appoint stewards and was in charge of field representatives, she was not the only contact for Local 1110 bargaining unit members, given the presence of many stewards, service representatives, and organizers. Although Randazzo was knowledgeable as to the provisions of the relevant collective agreements, it was observed that these were public documents. Although she may have been knowledgeable with respect to labour law practices, including the conduct of grievances, such knowledge was neither unique nor proprietary to Local 1110. In contrast, Mancinelli had broad powers concerning Local 1110, and he exercised those powers without much restraint. Mancinelli was the person in control of Local 1110. When the events occurred, Randazzo was its newly-demoted “Acting” Business Manager.[103]

The Divisional Court did not accept that the fact that the trial judge's references to the Uniform Constitution of the LIUNA District Council rendered his conclusion that Randazzo was not a fiduciary one that could not be sustained on appeal. In coming to the conclusion that he did the trial judge relied on the powers and roles that the key players actually played in the running of Local 1110, not on how those powers or roles were set out in any particular document. Furthermore, the Divisional Court did not agree that the trial judge reached his conclusion that Randazzo was not a fiduciary purely on the basis that there was someone senior to her or she had a reporting obligation. Rather, the trial judge made findings of fact as to Randazzo's powers in context and within the particular organization in which such powers could be exercised. The facts as found by the trial judge, amply supported his conclusion that Local 1110 was not at the mercy of, reliant on, or dependent on Randazzo.[104]

As the trial judge noted, what is confidential information is a determination to be made in the context of the circumstances. It must be considered in light of what items a departing employee rightfully may be able to take away from employment which include general skills and knowledge acquired on the job. Although the trial judge found that it would have been preferable for the Defendants to leave all equipment and documents behind when they left, mere possession of these items is not a breach of confidence. The trial judge found that the Appellants were unable to specifically prove what information had been either used or misused, or how. The trial judge also found that Randazzo's creation of a business plan for the Carpenters, using a report that she had prepared previously for Local 1110 as a guide and using information that was publicly available and not confidential, was only an incident of “precedent usage” and not a breach of confidence. In general, the trial judge found that the material said to have been retained by the Defendants lacked any “aura of confidentiality” and was generally available to the public. He made this finding after examining the material in detail and absent a palpable and overriding error, his findings were entitled to deference. The Divisional Court concluded that the findings made were available to the trial judge on the evidence before him.[105]

In Consbec Inc. v. Walker,[106] the trial judge dismissed the majority of Consbec's claims holding that Peter was not Consbec's fiduciary and had not breached his common-law duties as an employee. However, the judge held that Peter had failed to give Consbec reasonable notice before terminating his employment and awarded Consbec damages in that regard. In its appeal, Consbec contended that the trial judge committed a number of errors in dismissing Consbec's claim against Peter for breach of fiduciary duty. In the alternative, Consbec argued that the judge erred in finding that Peter had not breached his common-law duties of confidentiality, good faith, and fidelity he owed as an employee.[107]

In 1997, Rick hired Peter to work for Consbec. Initially, Peter worked at Consbec's head office. In June 1998, Peter went to Moncton, New Brunswick, as manager of the Eastern Division. In May 1999, Consbec opened a Western Division and Peter went to Kamloops, British Columbia to manage that office. The Western Division office was a 5-foot square space in front of a welding shop. The Western Division closed in 2009. Peter did not have a contract of employment with Consbec and his duties and responsibilities were never reduced to writing. Although Consbec sought to portray Peter as a “manager”, the trial judge found that he “can best be described as an estimator”, whose duties were “limited to managing his own daily activities of work and sometimes project site management and making arrangements for labour”. Peter's role was to solicit blasting and drilling contracts. Peter determined which projects were available to bid on from BC Bid, a website that lists public sector projects that provincial government departments, municipalities, etc. are undertaking. Peter then determined which contractors would likely bid on a particular project and contacted them to determine whether they would like a bid from Consbec. To prepare a bid, Peter found out as much information as he could about a particular job. Peter prepared bids using a Microsoft Excel spreadsheet that Richard had developed for Consbec. Peter provided Richard with the information he obtained about a particular project and Richard used the spreadsheet to independently prepare a bid. Peter and Richard discussed their respective bids and, if necessary, made adjustments. Richard had the final say. Richard was aware of all the bids Peter made. In the event that a formal contract was required after a bid was accepted, that contract was signed at Consbec's head office. From time to time, Peter signed-off with respect to the hours persons hired for a specific project worked. He sent all payroll and accounting documents to head office. Peter made no corporate decisions, nor was he asked to participate in corporate meetings. He did not have authority to sign Consbec cheques or make electronic transfers or payments from the company's accounts.[108]

The Court of Appeal rejected Consbec's argument that the trial judge erred in finding that Peter was not a fiduciary. Consbec alleged that contrary to the judge's finding that Peter was an estimator, Peter was in fact a key employee in whom Consbec placed considerable trust and confidence. Consbec's arguments amounted to an attempt to have the appellate Court retry the case and make findings of fact that differed from the trial judge's findings. That is something this Court can do only in limited circumstances. In coming to a conclusion with respect to Peter's role with Consbec the trial judge made detailed and comprehensive findings. As Consbec's claim that Peter was a fiduciary was based on a factual matrix it failed to prove at trial, there was no need to discuss the law relating to fiduciaries in detail. On the facts the trial judge found, Peter was not a person whom Consbec entrusted with discretionary powers that could affect Consbec's interests. Much like Gannon in Zoic Studios B.C. Inc. v. Gannon, 2015 BCCA 334, at paras. 60-64, 386 D.L.R. (4th) 662, who was found not to be a fiduciary even though she held the position of “executive creative director and visual effects supervisor”, Peter's authority was circumscribed and head office made all key decisions regarding the Western Division's operations.[109]

The trial judge rejected Consbec's claim that Peter took Consbec's Excel spreadsheet, took or destroyed Consbec's client (contact) list, and wiped an office computer clean. The Court of Appeal concluded that Consbec sought to have the appellate Court retry the case and make findings of fact that differed from the trial judge's findings. For example, Consbec challenged the judge's finding that Consbec failed to prove Peter took the Excel spreadsheet and used it to compete. In making that finding the judge referred not only to Peter's denial but also to Consbec's failure to present any direct evidence that Peter took the spreadsheet or expert evidence to support its allegation that someone took the spreadsheet and wiped a computer clean. In addition, the judge found that Consbec failed to prove even the existence of the contact list it alleged Peter took. In effect, the trial judge found that all that Peter took with him when he left Consbec were the general skills and knowledge he had acquired while working for that company. That is something he was entitled to do.[110]

In Enbridge Gas Distribution Inc. v. Marinaccio,[111] the motion judge found that Marinaccio owed a fiduciary duty to Enbridge and that he breached his fiduciary duty by secretly profiting at the expense of his employer. A business arrangement was made by Piro and Montaldi with Marinaccio who at the time was an operations supervisor with Enbridge with authority to retain third party contractors and to approve payment of invoices. Piro was a labourer who worked for various companies that did business with Enbridge. Montaldi was an accountant and financial planner. Enbridge often required repair work to be done on properties where Enbridge technicians had done the maintenance work. Piro would register business entities to do the work. Marinaccio would hire contractors to do the work. Montaldi would prepare the invoices to be given to Enbridge. Marinaccio would approve the invoices. Marinaccio, Piro and Montaldi would share the payments from Enbridge in predetermined percentages. Marinaccio had by the time of trial admitted that the entire scheme was a fraud. No work was ever done. All the invoices were phoney.[112]

Marinaccio had discretionary power both to hire outside contractors for Enbridge and to approve the payment of invoices they submitted. Enbridge was undoubtedly vulnerable to the exercise of that power because Marinaccio used his power to defraud his employer of over $6.5 million over the course of six and a half years. The fact that Marinaccio had the authority, opportunity and ability to perpetrate such a large-scale fraud on his employer over such a prolonged period of time was some evidence that he possessed the hallmarks of a fiduciary duty: discretionary power over a correspondently vulnerable employer.[113]

In upholding this finding, the Court of Appeal cautioned that it should not be taken to signify that many mid-level employees of large corporations will owe a fiduciary duty to their employer. The finding in this case not only rested on its particulars facts but was largely uncontested. If the question whether Marinaccio owed a fiduciary duty to Enbridge had been more vigorously challenged, the motion judge may have taken a different view.[114]

In Movassaghi v. Steels Industrial Products Ltd.,[115] the court concluded that Dr. Movassaghi owed a fiduciary duty to Gasmaster before and after his departure. Dr. Movassaghi was the general manager of Gasmaster and its key employee regarding all matters relating to the development and application of the RPC technology. There was no question that Dr. Movassaghi was part of the “top management” of Gasmaster even though he was not an officer or director of that company.

A finding of an employee as “key” does not necessarily mean the employee was in a fiduciary capacity to the company.[116] In Zoic Studios BC Inc. v. Gannon,[117] the employer was a computer visual effects studio which specialized in feature films, television shows, commercials, video games, advertising and online content. Zoic LA chose willing employees to relocate to Vancouver to set up the office. Two senior employees were chosen including the defendant. In 2008, the employee was elevated to executive creative director. She also held the role of visual effects supervisor. The employee reported directly to Zoic LA.
The trial judge concluded that substantively there is little difference between the categorical and principled approach to determining whether an employee is a fiduciary, stating:
… It appears the ability of the employee to control the legal or economic interests of the employer is an important function of the fiduciary in both approaches.

In any case, under either approach I cannot find that Ms. Gannon stood in a fiduciary position to Zoic BC. Admittedly, this is a case that comes very close to the line. Had Ms. Gannon had any additional authority I would have concluded that she was in a fiduciary position. As it stands, however, in my view, Ms. Gannon did not rise to that level.

It is not disputed that Ms. Gannon had never occupied the position of an officer or director of Zoic BC. Equally, it is also not disputed that Ms. Gannon was the “top employee” in Zoic BC. This fact alone, however, is not enough to engender a fiduciary relationship between Ms. Gannon and Zoic BC.[118]

Under either approach, the trial judge could not find that the employee stood in a fiduciary position to the employer. The fact that she was the “top employee” in Zoic BC was not enough to establish a fiduciary relationship between the employee and the employer. The evidence did not support a finding that the employee had the ability to affect her employer's legal or economic interests, an element that is necessary for both the principled and the categorical approaches to determination of fiduciary status:[119]

In summary, I find that while Ms. Gannon was the top employee in Vancouver, her control and authority of the company was significantly limited by Zoic LA. She had the authority to hire and dismiss, but this was limited to transitional hires. She did not have any sort of authority that could affect the financial or legal interests of Zoic BC. She could not spend more than $1,000 without approval, she could not unilaterally change daily rates charged to clients. She could not contractually bind Zoic BC. Her position did not put Zoic BC in a vulnerable position.[120]

The trial judge also observed that the structure of the employer must be viewed in relation to Zoic LA. The employer was a wholly owned subsidiary. It would be artificial to view the structure of the employer on its own, without regard to the guiding influence and oversight of Zoic LA. While the employee may have been the “top employee”, she still answered to the management of Zoic LA. The management of Zoic LA was the top management of both Zoic studios. The control and authority of Zoic BC lay with them. The employee did not have the authority to sign contracts for Zoic BC to provide visual effects to clients. If she did not have the authority to bind Zoic BC to provide the one and only service it was designed to provide, it is difficult to see how she could have guided the interests of Zoic BC in any significant way. While the defendant was the top employee in Vancouver, her control and authority of the company was significantly limited by Zoic LA. She had the authority to hire and dismiss, but this was limited to transitional hires. She did not have any sort of authority that could affect the financial or legal interests of Zoic BC. She could not spend more than $1,000 without approval, she could not unilaterally change daily rates charged to clients. She could not contractually bind Zoic BC. Her position did not put Zoic BC in a vulnerable position.[121]

On appeal, the main thrust of the appellant's position was that the Trial Judge focused almost entirely on whether the employee had the legal authority to bind Zoic BC, and/or whether her authority at Zoic BC was unfettered and that the Trial Judge failed to consider whether the employee exercised discretionary power to affect Zoic BC's practical interests.[122] In dismissing the ground of appeal relating to breach of fiduciary duty, Justice Chiasson observed that the trial judge examined very thoroughly the authority of the employee, was alive to the law of fiduciary duty and that she considered the effect of the employee's authority on the interests of Zoic BC. The trial judge made no error of law. Her findings of fact were supported by the evidence.[123]

The Court of Appeal allowed the appeal to the extent only of remitting the matter to the trial judge with the direction that she consider whether an equitable accounting should be ordered arising out of the personal respondents' breach of their duty of fidelity and loyalty by competing with the appellant.[124]

A key employee is one who generally is responsible for guiding the business affairs of the employer, is involved in the decision-making process or is someone having access to confidential information that if disclosed could impair competitive advantage that the employer enjoys. In Laplante v. Hennessy-Craibe,[125] the plaintiff had operated the business of Pascalina's since 1992. The defendant, a student at Pascalina's between 1993 and 1995, became a teacher's aide at Pascalina's in 1996 and an instructor in 1998. Her duties as an instructor included choreography, choosing and purchasing costumes, as well as choosing hair styles and make-up for recitals and competitions. In 2008 the defendant entered into an employment agreement with Pascalina's for employment to teach dancing. There was no restrictive covenant in the employment agreement. In 2011 the defendant set up her own dance school business, competing with the plaintiff. The court concluded that the defendant's responsibility for the plaintiff's business did not come close to the necessary elements required for a key employee as outlined by Richardson J.A. in Imperial Sheet Metal Ltd. v. Landry:[126]

74. Richardson J.A. In Imperial Sheet Metal suggested the following non-exhaustive code of necessary elements as to what are the constituent elements for a key employee to attract the fiduciary obligation suggested here by the plaintiff. A “key” employee is: (1) an integral and indispensable component of the management team that is responsible for guiding the business affairs of the employer; (2) necessarily involved in the decision-making process; and (3), therefore, has broad access to confidential information that if disclosed would significantly impair the competitive advantages that the former employer enjoyed. These employees fall within the categories: “top management”, “senior management” or “key management”.

The fact that several students and instructors followed her to her new business did not in and of itself constitute proof of the plaintiff's claim that the defendant was a key employee. The defendant returned or destroyed all registration forms and any and all other property of Pascalina's that she had in her possession.[127]

In Planit Search Inc. v. Mann,[128] the fact that Soucy, a “Senior Account Manager” for the plaintiff who did not have persons reporting to him, may have been privy the plaintiff's databases which might have contained some confidential information regarding candidates or clients to perform his work, did not by itself, mean that Soucy was a fiduciary of the plaintiff.

The plaintiff was a placement agency which specialized in IT personnel with expertise in enterprise resource planning software. Soucy was a commissioned recruiting contractor. His duties were to post available positions, identify and contact potential employee, set up interviews with possible candidates and place selected candidates in the available positions. In between periods of employment with the plaintiff, Soucy worked as a recruitment contractor for competitors of the plaintiff. Soucy now worked for a competitor.[129] During the 14 years during which the plaintiff had operated, it created a database of about 80,000 IT candidates, being persons with IT expertise mostly in the ERP area. The plaintiff also created a database which included approximately 12,000 clients who used IT personnel with the required IT skills. Some of the candidates and clients in the databases had never been involved in any business arrangement with the plaintiff. The candidates in the database were better described as candidates and potential future candidates. Likewise, the clients in the database were better described as clients and potential clients. The databases were available to the plaintiff's employees to help them generate business for the plaintiff. After his departure from the plaintiff, Soucy contacted some potential candidates including some which the plaintiff alleged were “its candidates” from the databases and IBM, which the plaintiff alleged was “its client” from the databases, for the purpose of placing employees in the IT area. However, the court concluded that it was not known whether those persons or company were in the plaintiff's databases or what information there was about them. It was not known if they were actual candidates and clients of the plaintiff or potential candidates or clients. It was not known whether the information regarding them was publicly available or known to competitors in the industry. It was not known whether they had a contract with the plaintiff and, if so, on what terms.[130]

The court concluded that there was no evidence that Soucy was in a position to make any managerial or corporate decisions on behalf of the plaintiff. He had no discretion to make such decisions on behalf of the plaintiff. Given his previous comings and goings at the plaintiff, it was hard to imagine that the plaintiff would consider him a key or high level employee or provide Soucy with any discretionary authority for serious matters. There were no other hallmarks of a fiduciary relationship. There was not an “above-average level of trust” in or responsibility given to Soucy.[131]

In Future Shop v. Northwest-Atlantic (B.C.),[132] the court, in holding that one of the individual defendants was not a fiduciary, emphasized that the “reality” of the situation did not match the “characterizations” presented in the plaintiff's materials:

Ms. Moseley had, despite her title, no authority to bind Future Shop in relation to real estate transactions. She had no authority to make important decisions, and her spending authority was limited to $5,000.00 without the approval of Gary Patterson. All offers to lease had to be discussed and approved by Patterson before they were issued and all such offers were, in any event, conditional on the President's approval.

Similarly, the absence of a title will not in itself prevent fiduciary level accountability.[133] In Harris Scientific Products Ltd. v. Araujo,[134] the court reviewed the defendant's situation and held that he was not one of the plaintiff's key employees:

paratext.ital: Although David Araujo was, historically and overall, a valued employee of Harris, at the time of his dismissal, he did not have the power to put Harris at legal or practical risk.

para.paratext: The law establishes that the label of “officer” or “director” is not a mandatory pre-requisite to fiduciary obligations: Lac Minerals. The fact that David Araujo was neither an officer nor a director of Harris is clearly not determinative of whether he should be characterized as a key employee. It is also clear that, when assessing the role of a specific employee, the court must take into account the size and nature of the business in addition to the responsibilities of the individual employee. Reminding myself that the law requires the court to examine the content or substance of a relationship and not its form, the court nevertheless concludes that the evidence in this case establishes that Mr. Araujo did not have the scope to unilaterally affect the legal or practical interests of Harris: Mr. Araujo's work was essentially done at Mr. Spenceley's direction.

The Harris environment was small; Mr. Araujo was given both a title to better deal with Harris customers and the opportunity of dealing with some of Harris' key contacts. I accept Mr. Araujo's evidence that the business of Harris was relatively straightforward and easy. The fact that an employee has occasion to meet with an employer's key contacts does not necessarily mean that the introduced employee becomes a key employee.
(Emphasis in original.)

A fiduciary duty may be imposed on lower level employees, including those with little control or authority, if their functions are essential to the employer's business, thus rendering them “key personnel”.[135] However, an employee's sales volumes and the size of sales alone do not reflect a fiduciary duty, but rather the employer's decision not to protect itself by a restrictive covenant or otherwise.[136] As a general principle, however, an employee unable to “act” independently, i.e., without the approval of another, will not normally be considered a fiduciary.[137] In the right circumstances, even administrative employees may be found to have fiduciary obligations.[138]

It is also necessary to examine the employee's overall responsibilities with the employer, particularly the degree of control and authority the employee had with respect to the employer's operations or some part thereof.[139] Canadian Aero Service Ltd. v. O'Malley[140] made it clear that the courts will classify those employees who exercise “the real influence in directing the corporation” as fiduciaries.

A number of other factors have also influenced the courts in their determination of whether former employees will be held accountable as fiduciaries, including their remuneration, the influence they had over customers, their knowledge of the business, whether or not they had signing authority, their relation to corporate opportunities and customers, and the length of time they were in their positions.[141]

In Evans v. Sports Corp.[142] a sports agent was neither a director nor shareholder of the employer and could not hire or promote any employee. The trial judge upheld his employer's counterclaim by finding that the sports agent had solicited the employer's employees and clients and had breached both the restrictive covenant in his employment contract and his fiduciary duty to his former employer.

The trial judge rejected the employee's submission that he was but a minor cog in the employer's operation noting that the employer entrusted the “Czech-Slovak Pipeline” to the employee for six years, with little or no supervision. With respect to many clients, the employee was the only senior employee they knew and had worked with. The Court of Appeal was satisfied that the evidence disclosed that the employee was the face and voice of the employer in North America for those Czech and Slovak professional hockey clients recruited by Henys and Kadlecek, both of whom were paid by the employer to recruit players on its behalf. The employee was entrusted with primary responsibility for the development of these players, and was expected to and did develop close personal relationships with them. The element of vulnerability is apparent. The Court of Appeal stated:

As this court pointed out, however, in Anderson, Smyth & Kelly Custom Brokers Ltd. v. World Wide custom Brokers Ltd, 1996 ABCA 169 at para 15, 39 Alta LR (3d) 411, the status of a fiduciary does not emanate from holding corporate office. Rather, it relates to the responsibilities entrusted to an employee, including any attendant power to affect the economic interests of the company. In this case, while the Eastern European market was merely a segment of the overall business operations of TSC, Evans was entrusted with primary responsibility for its successful operation. TSC paid Henys and Kadlecek to find and recruit players who were then turned over to Evans. Evans could then use the power and influence arising from the personal relationship developed with these players, either for the benefit of TSC, or for himself. The great majority of the revenues flowing to Evans and his company, after he left TSC, were from the players originally entrusted to his care by TSC.[143]

The Court of Appeal observed that the situation was akin to the appropriation of a corporate opportunity; namely, players entrusted to the employee to develop on behalf of the employer were diverted to his own benefit.[144]

The Court of Appeal did not subscribe to the view that a termination of employment will automatically relieve a former employee of ongoing fiduciary obligations. It was only after the employee gave notice that he would be departing that the employer required that he immediately leave his office and asserted that it had no further need for his services. While the court did not condone the failure of the employer to make payment for the five-day balance of the term, it was doubtful that the breach to make payment constituted a wrongful dismissal and, in any event, involved no repudiation of the employment contract. In these circumstances, the employer's relatively minor breach of contract was irrelevant to the employee's ongoing fiduciary obligations and did not serve to relieve him of them.[145]

In analyzing whether an employee is a fiduciary, it is necessary to look to the cumulative effect of all factors that relate to the ability to act and to control the corporation. Making use of the test in Frame v. Smith,[146] it must then be asked whether the employee, in exercising the discretion or power he or she had, could unilaterally exercise that power or discretion so as to affect the employer's interests. Then, most importantly, the employer must demonstrate that it was peculiarly vulnerable to or at the mercy of the former employee.
In Jones v. Klassen,[147] the court held that the plaintiff was in a position of power with the defendant such that he was the “face” of Edward Jones:

Within the framework of what Edward Jones offered all its clients, Mr. Klassen had the discretion to make recommendations for purchases, sales, and in essence, all the day-to-day decisions relating to Edward Jones' clients in Mr. Klassen's territory. Edward Jones' success in that St. Albert office was entirely dependent upon Mr. Klassen's activities and interaction with the clients of that office. Mr. Klassen argues that because he was just one of 10,000 investment associates of Edward Jones, he was a small fish in the sea. However, he was the very biggest fish — indeed, the only fish — in that office.

Accordingly, in my view it is reasonable to find Mr. Klassen to be in a fiduciary relationship with Edward Jones. He certainly was able to exercise some discretion or power, and exercising that discretion or power affected Edward Jones' legal and practical interests. It is clear Edward Jones was particularly vulnerable to Mr. Klassen's discretion and power when one considers the contract Edward Jones had him sign before the company educated him and hired him on as one of its investment advisors, and when one considers the steps Edward Jones promptly took to effect damage control when he abruptly abandoned ship.
(Emphasis in original.)

Courts will not reach the conclusion that an employee owes fiduciary obligations lightly. Firemaster Oilfield Services Ltd. v. Safety Boss (Canada) (1993) Ltd.,[148] provides a good summary of the relevant case law:

In my view, it is ludicrous to conclude that Campbell was a beneficiary “peculiarly vulnerable to or at the mercy of the fiduciary (Cusson) holding the discretion or power”. A finding of vulnerability, in my view, would perpetrate manifest unfairness on Cusson. It would put him in the position of having been a mere flunky, just another salesman, totally answerable to Campbell, but tied to Campbell more dramatically than he would have been had a restrictive covenant been negotiated. Put another way, the Court would be taking an ordinary employee, with no power or authority, and making him more because of the nature of his sales job and the location of his assignment. In my view, this is not warranted, when clearly Cusson was not treated as a key employee in any way by Campbell or others prior to his resignation. Further, had a restrictive covenant been negotiated, it would have been subject to the scrutiny of the Court.

In Physique Health Club Ltd. v. Carlsen (1996) 193 A.R. 196 (C.A.); leave refused [1997] S.C.C.A. No. 40, the Court of Appeal of Alberta held that a Court should not use the requirement of notice to impose, through the back door, a quasi-restrictive covenant. In that case, the Court accepted the finding of the trial judge that the employee, Carlsen, was a fiduciary employee but, held that as such he need only have provided six weeks' notice of departure. In my view, the Court's comments should similarly apply to a characterization of an employee as “key” or otherwise. That is, a Court should be cautious in utilizing this characterization to impose, through the back door, a quasi-restrictive covenant.

In that regard, counsel for the Defendants argues that in an employment context, the Courts have been particularly reluctant to impose fiduciary duties, and the Supreme Court of Canada has made it clear that fiduciary obligations should not be frequently imposed. The fiduciary obligation has been described by the Supreme Court as “the law's blunt tool” which must be reserved for situations in which there is a real need for the special protection that equity affords: LAC Minerals Ltd. v. International Corona Resources Ltd. (supra) at 60-64. That may be overstating the caution referred to by the Supreme Court. However, the need for caution in a situation such as this, of an employee who appears to be similar in terms of function and responsibility to his colleagues and who is not subject to a restrictive covenant is borne out by the following statement of Mr. Justice Paul in Barton Insurance Brokers Ltd. v. Irwin (supra) at 88:

In the case at bar, I am of the respectful view that the conclusions of the learned trial judge were soundly based in law and fact. Absent an enforceable agreement to refrain from soliciting former customers, I am not of the view that any duty, fiduciary or otherwise, should have been found to prevent Ms. Irwin from canvassing former clients. In cases involving activity by key or senior former employees, or by directors in situations disclosing manifest unfairness, such as found in Smith Paper Ltd. [57134 Manitoba Ltd.] or Tree Savers International Ltd., a court may be persuaded to grant injunctive relief or to award damages against former employees. However, the general interest of the public in free competition and the consideration that in general citizens should be free to pursue new opportunities, in my opinion, requires courts to exercise caution in imposing restrictive duties on former employees in less than clear circumstances. Generally speaking, as I noted from the earlier authorities referred to, the law favours the granting of freedom to individuals to pursue economic advantage through mobility in employment. To find liability against the defendants on the facts of this case would, in my view, not be appropriate.

In certain circumstances, which I think would be relatively rare, a former employee of less than senior management or directorial status might be found subject to a fiduciary duty for instance—a “key employee” finding might serve to found such a duty. But I do not believe that courts should be easily persuaded to find that ordinary employees would be subject to such continuing duties.
Clearly, this caution has been exercised by other courts. In RW Hamilton Ltd. v. Aeroquip Corp. (1988), 22 C.P.R. (3d) 135, at 143 (Ont. H.C.J.) Mr. Justice Smith stated:

In my view, the approach of the courts has struck a balance between the need for compelling persons who occupy such high positions in the business or corporate world that the law should prevent the few who could easily succumb to the temptation of serving two masters from so doing, and freedom of trade. They should be made to conform to a high standard of ethical behaviour even if by doing so the courts may appear to be encroaching upon the requirements of freedom of trade. Not all managerial positions should lead to the imposition of the very high duty of a trustee lest the law commit a high proportion of employees in this province to slavery.

Employers are protected from the faithless actions of top management by the law of trusts and, failing that, in respect of lower level employees by certain elementary rules of decency that will prevent theft of confidential information and of customer lists. Beyond this the law dare not go, preferring that the business community rely on contractual arrangements. This is precisely what the plaintiff did when he later hired Peter Coulen on a contract that included a three-month, non-competition clause.

I have found Cusson was clearly no more than an ordinary employee. He had no management status or responsibilities, and I have not found any other circumstances to justify the relatively rare finding that he was key. He should be granted the advantage of the law, which, as stated above, favours the granting of freedom to individuals to pursue economic advantage through mobility of employment, in this case, not just for alternative employment, but also to pursue a business opportunity.
